revision_history.draft:
A nail loses one millimeter from its head each year.
No one measures it. The wall remains
a constant width, and the picture stays hung.

The zipper on my sister's jacket has learned
the exact length of her throat—
that particular tug at 4:23 AM when she pulls it down,
before her mind has named the temperature,
before the body decides to shiver.

I found a toast rack in the cabinet dated 1976.
Each slot is slightly narrower than the last,
a millimeter stolen from every morning.
The bread fits anyway. No one at the table
has ever suspected time of this precision.

In the basement, the fluorescent light above the stairs
flickers once at 12:01 AM and again at 365.4 days later,
not failing but performing a small, mechanical
hesitation—no one home, no one checking,
just the ballast's soul letting go for an evening.

My mother's hands have widened.
She says it isn't her body but the chairs
they sit in all day, the kitchen table
that has worn into the shape of every family member's
repetition. She traces a crease and calls it mine.

A switchplate on the living room wall holds a dent
not from anything physical hitting it—
that would be too obvious—but from the house
expanding in summer, pulling inward at the studs,
and the plastic giving ever so slightly.
No one remounts it. The gap is now part of the room.

At 2 AM the coffee maker clicks on by itself.
The water heats what isn't there.
This happens four nights out of seven.
On the fifth, something in the kitchen
has kept perfect stillness—absolute,
the way a lake doesn't know it's freezing.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The dent in the switchplate — "not from anything physical hitting it" is the strongest single line in the poem because it earns its strangeness through precise, almost scientific detail before the reader has any emotional stake. The fluorescent light flickering at precisely 12:01 AM and again after a year also lands because it's specific enough to feel like an observation rather than a mood.

The toast rack with narrowing slots is strong — "a millimeter stolen from every morning" gives the abstraction of time a concrete verb, and the final image (no one at the table has ever suspected) trusts the reader without explaining too much. The jacket zipper at 4:23 AM is alive because it's grounded in a real hour with a body doing something before consciousness catches up.

The light switch "performing a small, mechanical / hesitation" — that's good sensory language for an object that should just click but doesn't.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat (lines 13–17 of the draft).** The mother's hands have widened into a paragraph about chairs and tables wearing shapes from repeated sitting. This is the poem *telling* us what time does instead of showing it. "She traces a crease and calls it mine" — this could work, but it's buried in explanatory prose around it: "My mother's hands have widened / She says it isn't her body." The line-by-line explanation drains the image's power. **Direction:** Cut or rewrite entirely into a single concrete moment. What does she actually see? A crease in what? Let the reader infer.

**Sentimentality (lines 21–24).** "At 2 AM the coffee maker clicks on by itself. / The water heats what isn't there." This is a beautiful image, but then "something in the kitchen / has kept perfect stillness" moves into vague emotional summary — "absolute" is doing that work poorly. **Direction:** End with the physical fact: what does the water do? Stay with the object's behavior.

**Cliché by accident (line 10).** "The bread fits anyway" — this reads as a throwaway line that could fill a gap, and it's close enough to "no matter how much I love you, you'll never fit" territory. It softens what was sharpening. **Direction:** Make the bread not fit or barely fit. The friction will do more.

**Redundancy / structural padding (lines 18–20).** The basement passage has three separate domestic objects — a switchplate, a floor, and a coffee maker — but each gets its own paragraph with essentially the same move: object does something unusual; no one notices. Three examples of the same pattern is weaker than one that's fully developed. **Direction:** Choose one

revision_history.draft:
A ballast holds its flicker at 120 minutes,
the fluorescent light above the stairs
performing its small, mechanical
hesitation — no one home, no one checking.

The radiator cap lifts once a night.
Not steam. Not smoke. Nothing to see.
Just aluminum doing what it was cast for,

and the toast rack in the cabinet bears
its grooves narrower by fractions
no one has measured but the bread
still leans into each slot, still slides home.

My sister's jacket zipper knows
the exact length of her throat at 4:23 AM —
that particular pull below the collar,
before temperature names itself,

before shiver. The coffee maker clicks on
at two, heats what isn't there.
This happens four out of seven mornings.

On the fifth, the kitchen holds
a stillness so complete it almost

moves—a lake before it freezes,
a crease in my mother's palm
that is not her body but the chair
she sits in all day. She traces it.
It is not a story. It is the shape

of every morning she has leaned forward.

A switchplate on the living room wall
holds a dent not from anything physical—
the house expands in summer, pulls inward,
and plastic gives ever so slightly.
No one remounts it. The gap

is now part of the room's exact dimensions,

which no one measures. A nail loses
a millimeter each year from its head.
The wall stays constant. The picture hangs.

Bread finds the narrowest slot.
It does not fit. It barely doesn't.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision

---

### 1. What's Alive

The switchplate dent — "not from anything physical hitting it" is the strongest single line in the poem because it earns its strangeness through precise, almost scientific detail before the reader has any emotional stake.

The radiator cap lifting once a night: "Just aluminum doing what it was cast for" gives time a mechanical verb without explaining it. The 4:23 AM zipper on my sister's jacket — that exact hour is alive because it commits to a specific moment where consciousness hasn't yet registered cold.

The toast rack with narrowing slots earns its precision: "a millimeter stolen from every morning." That line trusts the reader and does no editorializing.

The fluorescent light flickering at 12:01 AM and again after a year — that's good sensory language for an object that should just click but doesn't. The repetition is accidental, not performed.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / explanation (lines 9–14).** "The bread fits anyway" — close to greeting-card territory. The bread barely fitting or not fitting would do more. "My mother's hands have widened" into the paragraph about chairs wearing shapes is the poem *telling* us what time does instead of showing it. **Direction:** Cut or rewrite entirely into a single concrete moment. What does she actually see? A crease in what? Let the reader infer.

**Redundancy / structural padding (lines 18–20).** The basement passage has three separate domestic objects — switchplate, floor, coffee maker — but each gets its own paragraph with essentially the same move: object does something unusual; no one notices. Three examples of the same pattern is weaker than one that's fully developed. **Direction:** Choose one and develop it ruthlessly.

**Cliché by accident (line 10).** "The bread fits anyway" — close enough to "no matter how much I love you, you'll never fit" territory. It softens what was sharpening. **Direction:** Make the bread barely slide in or not at all.

**Weak line break (line 24).** "It is the shape / of every morning she has leaned forward." The break on "shape" doesn't create meaningful tension — it's a pause where none is needed. **Direction:** Break after a word that earns the line turn, like "every morning" or "leans."

**Abstraction (line 17).** "She traces it. / It is not a story." This names what the poem has been doing — showing objects — and then labels it as meaning. **Direction:** Cut this line entirely. Let the final image carry the weight: the crease in her hand, which she traces.

**Line count / pacing.** The draft is 28 lines but reads like closer to 35 because of padding

revision_history.draft:
A ballast holds its flicker at 120 minutes,
the fluorescent light above the stairs
performing its small, mechanical
hesitation — no one home, no one checking.

The radiator loses a millimeter each year from its head.
The wall accommodates. The wall does not expand — it holds
the shape of what has been asked of it, which is everything.

My sister's jacket zipper knows the exact length
of her throat at 4:23 AM. That particular pull below the collar,
before temperature names itself, before shiver.

The coffee maker clicks on at two, heats air.
This happens four out of seven mornings — the fifth
the kitchen holds so still it almost

moves, a lake freezing over, the crease
my mother's palm keeps finding after every seat,
not a story but the exact dent where her weight has pressed.

A switchplate on the living room wall
holds a gap I have measured with my thumb:
three millimeters. The house expands in summer,
pulls inward each fall like a breath, and plastic gives

so slightly that no one remounts it — the missing
circle is now part of what this outlet demands.
I plug things into it. They still fit.

The bread finds the narrowest slot in the rack
and does not fit. It barely doesn't. The second piece
falls a little further, each morning narrower

by fractions no one has measured but the bread
keeps sliding home anyway — that slight stagger,
that nearly there, the way you almost stop

at 4:23 and find yourself at 4:25 still breathing,
still in the house. The slot keeps getting

tighter by millimeters. Bread knows this.
Bread has been watching what happens
when you keep putting it in.

The toast rack grooves close a fraction each year.
No one notices until the bread

no longer glides but nudges, and even then,
the nudge is small — just enough to feel
the loss the way my mother feels her palm's

particular dent, not remembering how or when
it got there. She traces it with a fingertip
on any flat surface. It is not a story.

It is the shape of every morning she has leaned forward into.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The switchplate with the gap measured by thumb — that is the poem's strongest sustained passage. The radiator losing a millimeter from its head, the toast rack narrowing slot by fractions, and the fluorescent light flickering at ungodly hours are all precise, quiet observations where objects do strange things without anyone noticing. These earn their strangeness through specificity of action: "no one has measured," "a millimeter stolen," "it barely doesn't." The language trusts the reader to feel the uncanny without being told it's uncanny.

The jacket zipper knowing throat-length at 4:23 AM is a good hour because it commits — that time, that light, that cold before shiver arrives. The bread sliding home in the narrower rack also works well as an image; "broadly tight" does real work with its double meaning (wide and narrow).

The poem's core angle — time acting on objects without consciousness registering — is genuinely interesting.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / explanation (lines 9–14).** The passage about my sister, the morning at 4:23, the jacket zipper, the toast rack, and then "the bread fits anyway" — this is where the poem explains what it spent eight lines building. "Before temperature names itself" and "before shiver" are good; "the bread still slides home" is not. That line tells us the object did its job instead of letting the reader see the sliding fail or barely succeed, which would do far more. **Direction:** Cut the final sentence entirely. Let the rack narrow to a point where the bread doesn't fit — that's already the image doing the work.

**Redundancy (lines 18–20).** The basement passage has three separate domestic objects — switchplate, floor, coffee maker — but each gets its own paragraph with essentially the same move: object does something unusual; no one notices. Three examples of the same pattern is weaker than one that's fully developed. **Direction:** Choose one and develop it ruthlessly. Cut at least one.

**Weak line break (line 24).** "It is not a story." / "It is the shape" — this names what the poem has been doing, which drains the final image of its power. The crease in her palm is already carrying that weight. **Direction:** Remove entirely. End on "a flat surface."

**Cliché by accident (line 10).** "The bread fits anyway" — close enough to "no matter how much I love you, you'll never fit" territory. It softens what was sharpening. **Direction:** Make the failure more precise: barely slide in, or not at all.

**Abstraction / summary (lines 21–24).** The passage about my mother tracing a cre

revision_history.draft:
A ballast holds its flicker at 120 minutes,
the fluorescent light above the stairs
performing its small, mechanical
hesitation — no one home, no one checking.

The radiator loses a millimeter each year from its head.
The wall does not expand; it pulls
the plaster thin where the paint meets the corner,
a crease my mother's palm keeps finding after every seat.

My sister's jacket zipper knows the exact length
of her throat at 4:23 AM. That particular pull below the collar —
before temperature names itself, before shiver —

the coffee maker clicks on at two, heats air.
This happens four out of seven mornings — the fifth
the kitchen holds so still it almost

moves, a lake freezing over, the dent
my mother's palm keeps finding after every seat,
not a story but the exact shape of her weight.

A switchplate on the living room wall
holds a gap I have measured with calipers: three millimeters.
The house expands in summer,
pulls inward each fall like a breath, and plastic gives

so slightly that no one remounts it — the missing
circle is now part of what this outlet demands.
I plug things into it. They still fit.

The bread finds the narrowest slot in the rack
and does not fit. It barely holds its place,
each morning narrower

by fractions I have never recorded but the bread
keeps sliding home anyway — that slight stagger,
the way you almost stop

at 4:23 and find yourself at 4:25 still breathing,
still in the house. The slot keeps tightening.

Bread knows this.
Bread has been watching what happens
when you keep putting it in.

The toast rack grooves close a fraction each year.
No one notices until the bread

no longer glides but stops mid-rack, its weight

revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The switchplate with the gap measured by thumb — that is the poem's strongest sustained passage. The radiator losing a millimeter from its head, the toast rack narrowing slot by fractions, and the fluorescent light flickering at ungodly hours are all precise, quiet observations where objects do strange things without anyone noticing. These earn their strangeness through specificity of action: "no one has measured," "a millimeter stolen," "it barely doesn't." The language trusts the reader to feel the uncanny without being told it's uncanny.

The jacket zipper knowing throat-length at 4:23 AM is a good hour because it commits — that time, that light, that cold before shiver arrives. The bread sliding home in the narrower rack also works well as an image; "broadly tight" does real work with its double meaning (wide and narrow).

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / explanation (lines 9–14).** The passage about my sister, the morning at 4:23, the jacket zipper, the toast rack, and then "the bread fits anyway" — this is where the poem explains what it spent eight lines building. **Direction:** Cut the final sentence entirely. Let the rack narrow to a point where the bread doesn't fit — that's already the image doing the work.

**Redundancy (lines 18–20).** The basement passage has three separate domestic objects — switchplate, floor, coffee maker — but each gets its own paragraph with essentially the same move: object does something unusual; no one notices. Three examples of the same pattern is weaker than one that's fully developed. **Direction:** Choose one and develop it ruthlessly. Cut at least one.

**Weak line break (line 24).** "It is not a story." / "It is the shape" — this names what the poem has been doing, which drains the final image of its power. The crease in her palm is already carrying that weight. **Direction:** Remove entirely. End on "a flat surface."

**Cliché by accident (line 10).** "The bread fits anyway" — close enough to "no matter how much I love you, you'll never fit" territory. It softens what was sharpening. **Direction:** Make the failure more precise: barely slide in, or not at all.

**Abstraction / summary (lines 21–24).** The passage about my mother tracing a crease with her palm — "not a story but the exact shape of her weight" and "it is not remembering how or when" — retreats into explanation. The poem tells us what it means rather than letting the physical gesture do its own work. **Direction:** Cut all language that names the metaphor. End on the action: the fingertip tracing

final_poem:
The radiator loses a millimeter each year,
its head thinning like a breath
it holds too long. My mother's palm
keeps finding the dent after every seat.

Her sister's jacket zipper knows exactly
the length of her throat at 4:23 AM — that particular pull below the collar,
before temperature names itself, before shiver —

the coffee maker clicks on at two and heats air.
This happens four out of seven mornings. The fifth

the kitchen holds so still it almost
moves like a lake freezing over, the dent
my mother's palm keeps finding after every seat,
not a story but the exact shape.

A switchplate on the living room wall
holds a gap I have measured with calipers: three millimeters.
The plastic gives so slightly that no one remounts it — the missing
circle is now part of what this outlet demands. I plug things in and they still fit,

which is strange, because if you look closely,
the bread finds the narrowest slot in the rack
and barely slides in, each morning fractionally

tighter by fractions I have never recorded — that slight stop,
that arrested position where you almost
stop at 4:23 but keep going to 4:25
still breathing, still in the house. The slot keeps tightening.

The bread knows this.
It keeps sliding home anyway.
